DOI: 10.1016/S1872-2067(11)60383-5 ARTICLE Silica-Bonded N-Propyl Diethylenetriamine Sulfamic Acid as a Recyclable Solid Acid Catalyst for the Synthesis of Æ -Aminonitriles Tahere RAHI 1 , Mojtaba BAGHERNEJAD 1 , Khodabakhsh NIKNAM 2,* 1 Department of Chemistry, Gachsaran Branch, Islamic Azad University, Gachsaran, Iran 2 Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Sciences, Persian Gulf University, Bushehr 75169, Iran Abstract: Silica-bonded N-propyl diethylenetriamine sulfamic acid (SBPDSA) is employed as a recyclable catalyst to synthesize Ä®-aminonitriles. These syntheses involved one-pot condensation of an aldehyde, an amine, and trimethylsilyl cyanide under mild reaction conditions at room temperature. SBPDSA was recycled seven times in the condensation of benzaldehyde, aniline, and trimethylsilyl cyanide without reduction of its catalytic activity. Key words: silica-bonded N-propyl diethylenetriamine sulfamic acid; Ä®-aminonitrile; solid acid; aldehyde; heterogeneous catalyst The addition of cyanide anions to imines (the Strecker reac- tion) [1] is one of the most important and straightforward method to synthesize Ä®-aminonitriles, which are useful inter- mediates for the synthesis of amino acids [2] and nitro- gen-containing heterocycles such as thiadiazoles and imida- zoles [3,4]. The classical Strecker reaction is usually carried out in aqueous solution and the work-up procedure is tedious. Thus, several modifications of the Strecker reaction have been developed using a variety of cyanide reagents [5], such as diethyl phosphorocyanidate and Ä®-trimethylsiloxynitriles, as well as catalysts including InCl 3 [6], [bmim]BF 4 [7], mont- morillonite KSF clay [8], silica sulfuric acid [9], I 2 [10], Fe(Cp) 2 PF 6 [11], xanthan sulfuric acid [12], hydrophobic sul- fonic acid-based nanoreactors [13], silica-bonded S-sulfonic acid [14], sulfamic acid-functionalized magnetic Fe 3 O 4 nanoparticles [15], and silica-based ionic liquids [16], under various reaction conditions. Trimethylsilyl cyanide (TMSCN) is a safe and effective source of cyanide anions for the nu- cleophilic addition reactions of imines under mild conditions [17,18]. However, many of these methods require the use of expensive reagents, harsh conditions, extended reaction times, and also require tedious work-up that generates a large amount of toxic waste. Furthermore, many of these catalysts are deac- tivated or sometimes decomposed by amines and water that are present during imine formation. To overcome these problems, one-pot procedures have recently been developed for this transformation [19]. Several types of solid sulfonic acid-functionalized silica (both amorphous and ordered) have been synthesized and used as an alternative to traditional sulfonic acid resins and homo- geneous acids to catalyze chemical transformations [20â€“29]. In continuation of our studies on the design and application of solid acid catalysts in organic transformations [21â€“29], herein, we describe the application of silica-bonded N-propyl di- ethylenetriamine sulfamic acid (SBPDSA) as recyclable cata- lyst for the synthesis of Ä®-aminonitriles. 1 Experimental 1.1 Catalyst preparation 1.1.1 Preparation of silica propyl chloride Silica was first immersed in hydrochloric acid for 24 h and then washed with deionized water and dried under vacuum at 120 Â°C for 8 h. The activated silica (25.0 g) was suspended in Tahere RAHI et al. / Chinese Journal of Catalysis, 2012, 33: 1095â€“1100 dry toluene (300 ml) and then an excess of 3-chloropropyl- trimethoxysilane (25.0 ml) was added followed by triethyl- amine (2.5 ml) as a catalyst. The suspension was mechanically stirred as it was heated under reflux for 48 h. The reaction was cooled to room temperature, filtered, and then washed se- quentially with toluene, ethanol-water, deionized water, and methanol. The produced was dried under vacuum at 60 Â°C for 4 h to give chloropropyl silica (28.45 g). 1.1.2 Preparation of 3-diethylenetriamine-propyl silica (DTPS) To a mixture of chloropropyl silica (25 g) in anhydrous xy- lene (250 ml), an excess of diethylenetriamine (25 ml) was added and the mixture was heated under reflux with stirring for 24 h. The reaction was cooled to room temperature, filtered, and then washed with xylene and a large excess of ethanol. The product was dried under vacuum overnight at 80 Â°C to give DTPS (26.23 g, Scheme 1). 1.1.3 Preparation of SBPDSA To a magnetically stirred mixture of DTPS (5 g) in CHCl 3 (20 ml) at 0 Â°C, chlorosulfonic acid (2.00 g, 18 mmol) was added dropwise over 2 h. After the addition was complete, the mixture was stirred for 3 h until all HCl was removed from the reaction vessel. The mixture was filtered, washed with methanol (30 ml), and then dried at room temperature to give SBPDSA as a white powder (5.39 g) [30]. 1.2 General procedure for the synthesis of Ä®-aminonitrile derivatives A mixture of aldehyde (1 mmol), amine (1.5 mmol), TMSCN (1.5 mmol), and SBPDSA (0.07 g, 6.9 mol%) in EtOH (2 ml) was stirred at room temperature for an appropriate time. The reaction progress was followed by TLC using silica gel plates (SILG/UV 254). After the reaction was complete, the reaction mixture was filtered and washed with warm ethanol (5 ml Ã— 3). After cooling, the corresponding Ä®-aminonitrile products were purified by recrystallization from hot ethanol. The recovered catalyst was dried and reused for subsequent runs. Infrared (IR) spectra were measured on an IR spectrometer (Shimadzu, FT-IR-8000, Japan). 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra were obtained on Bruker Avance (DRX 500 MHz and 400 MHz) instruments in CDCl 3 . Melting points were recorded on a melting point apparatus (SMP1) in open capillary tubes and are uncorrected. All products were characterized by comparison of their IR, 1 H and 13 C NMR spectroscopic data and their melting points with reported values [5â€“16]. Calcd for C 14 H 18 N 2 O 3 : C, 64.10; H, 6.92; N, 10.68; Found: C, 63.89; H, 6.88; N, 10.51. 2 Results and discussion SBPDSA was prepared by the reaction of DTPS and chlo- rosulfonic acid in chloroform. The BET surface area calculated from nitrogen adsorption isotherms measured at the tempera- ture of liquid nitrogen was 762 m 2 /g and the total pore volume was calculated to be 0.1342 cm 3 /g. The content of S obtained from elemental analysis showed that typically a loading of 0.99 mmol/g H + was obtained. Thermal stability of a catalyst is an important requirement. The TG curve for the catalyst is shown in Fig. 1. Mass loss began at about 120 Â°C, which indicated decomposition of the catalyst. Therefore, the covalent bonds in the catalyst endow it with high thermal stability. To study the effect of catalyst loading on the condensation reaction of aldehydes and amines with TMSCN into the cor- responding Ä®-aminonitriles, the reaction of benzaldehyde and aniline with TMSCN was chosen as a model reaction (Table 1). It can be seen that the reaction did not proceed even after 24 h in the absence of this catalyst (Table 1, entry 1). Obviously, SBPDSA is important to catalyze the reaction. The optimal amount of SBPDSA was found to be 0.07 g (6.9 mol%) per 1 mmol of aldehyde in ethanol at room temperature. Although a lower catalyst loading of 0.05 or 0.03 g accomplished this 100 150 200 250 300 350 400 450 500 550 600 94 95 96 97 98 99 100 M a s s ( % ) Temperature ( o C) Fig. 1. TG curve of SBPDSA. Tahere RAHI et al. / Chinese Journal of Catalysis, 2012, 33: 1095â€“1100 condensation, 0.07 g of SBPDSA per 1 mmol of aldehyde was optimal in terms of reaction time and isolated yield. We used the optimized conditions (0.07 g/mmol of SBPDSA in ethanol at room temperature) for the condensation reaction of various aryl aldehydes and amines with TMSCN into the corresponding Ä®-aminonitriles. As shown in Table 2, both aromatic and aliphatic aldehydes reacted with amines and TMSCN in the presence of SBPDSA in this one-pot conden- sation to afford the corresponding Ä®-aminonitriles in excellent yield. Moreover, aldehydes with electron-donating or elec- tron-withdrawing groups, i.e., 4-methoxybenzaldehyde, 3,4,5-trimethoxybenzaldehyde, and 3-nitrobenzaldehyde, were converted into the corresponding Ä®-aminonitriles 1eâ€“1h in high yield (Table 2, entries 5â€“8). The acid sensitive substrate thio- phene-2-carbaldehyde gave the expected Ä®-aminonitrile 1i in very good yield (Table 2, entry 9). Aliphatic aldehydes such as pentanal and 2-methylpropanal gave the corresponding prod- ucts 1j and 1k in 73% and 75% yield, respectively (Table 2, entries 10 and 11). Also, as shown in Table 2, primary amines such as aniline, 4-chloroaniline, and benzylamine, and secon- dary amines such as morpholine were suitable for use in this one-pot condensation reaction. The reactions progressed rap- idly at room temperature and gave very good yields. The possibility of recycling the catalyst was examined using the reaction of benzaldehyde and aniline with TMSCN under the optimized conditions. Upon completion of the reaction, the mixture was filtered and then washed with warm ethanol. The product was recrystallized from hot ethanol. The recovered catalyst was dried and reused for subsequent runs. The recycled catalyst could be reused five times without any additional treatment or appreciable reduction in catalytic activity (Fig. 2). Finally, a comparative study of SBPDSA with other recently reported catalysts for condensation of benzaldehyde and ani- line with TMSCN was made, which revealed that SBPDSA is equally as efficient and reusable as other catalysts (Table 3). 3 Conclusions An efficient method was developed for the synthesis of Ä®-aminonitriles in high yield by using SBPDSA as a catalyst at room temperature. The catalyst was recovered and reused without any noticeable loss of activity. The heterogeneous conditions, green solvent, easy and clean work up, and sim- plicity of this procedure are improvements over many existing methods. References 1 Strecker A. ARTICLE Silica-Bonded N-Propyl Diethylenetriamine Sulfamic Acid as a Recyclable Solid Acid Catalyst for the Synthesis of α-Aminonitriles Tahere RAHI a Mojtaba BAGHERNEJAD a Khodabakhsh NIKNAM b * a Department of Chemistry, Gachsaran Branch, Islamic Azad University, Gachsaran, Iran b Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Sciences, Persian Gulf University, Bushehr 75169, Iran * Corresponding author. Tel: +98-771-4541494; Fax: +98-771-4545188 Silica-bonded N-propyl diethylenetriamine sulfamic acid (SBPDSA) is employed as a recyclable catalyst to synthesize a-aminonitriles. These syntheses involved one-pot condensation of an aldehyde, an amine, and trimethylsilyl cyanide under mild reaction conditions at room temperature. SBPDSA was recycled seven times in the condensation of benzaldehyde, aniline, and trimethylsilyl cyanide without reduction of its catalytic activity. Graphical abstract α-Aminonitriles were synthesized using silica-bonded N-propyldiethylenetriamine sulfamic acid as a recyclable solid acid catalyst for condensation of an aldehyde, amine, and trimethylsilyl cyanide at room temperature. coredata.dc:description: Silica-bonded N-propyl diethylenetriamine sulfamic acid (SBPDSA) is employed as a recyclable catalyst to synthesize a-aminonitriles. These syntheses involved one-pot condensation of an aldehyde, an amine, and trimethylsilyl cyanide under mild reaction conditions at room temperature. SBPDSA was recycled seven times in the condensation of benzaldehyde, aniline, and trimethylsilyl cyanide without reduction of its catalytic activity.
